docs.lead_paragraph: As a medical resident at a private hospital, am I an employee or a student? Do I have the right to form a union? In a reversal of decades of federal labor policy, the National Labor Relations Board recently said yes to the latter question, casting a new backdrop to an old debate about the status of young doctors at teaching hospitals, and emboldening residents at some hospitals to press for collective bargaining rights. In a case pitting the Boston Medical Center against the Committee of Interns and Residents, an advocacy group for house staff, as interns and residents are called, the labor relations board overturned its own landmark 1973 Cedars Sinai decision. In that decision the board ruled that private hospital residents were students, that they entered into residency only to fulfill certain educational requirements, and that, being students, they did not have the right to negotiate their hours or pay.

headline.main: Medical Residents, Yes, but Workers, Too

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George W. Bush has let it be known that he considers it fighting words to be compared to Bill Clinton. Still, it is hard to watch the Texas governor wend his way from schoolhouse to health clinic without recalling President Clinton's 1996 campaign. Here's Mr. Bush proclaiming that every child should know how to read by the third grade. ''There is nothing more fundamental than teaching our children how to read,'' he says, in proposing to spend $5 billion to address what he terms a national literacy crisis.

headline.main: Bush Strategy Recalls Clinton on the Trail in '96

docs.abstract: Campaign events that mirror those of Pres Clinton's 1996 campaign seem to be key tactic of Gov George W Bush's presidential campaign; Bush, since securing Republican nomination in Mar, has showcased issues usually associated wiht Democrats, just as Clinton once outflanked Republican Congress by embracing many of its issues; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: While the Giants followed the west Tennessee back roads to the little-known football outpost of Lambuth University to find wide receiver Ron Dixon in the college draft last weekend, they also pursued a well-worn path to their most familiar recruiting base, the Big Ten Conference. The Giants selected three players from the Big Ten in the 2000 National Football League draft, beginning with their top pick, running back Ron Dayne of Wisconsin. It was the 15th time the Giants have used their first draft choice on a Big Ten player. Since 1980, they have taken a player from the Big Ten or Notre Dame 12

docs.lead_paragraph: Jon S. Corzine may be running only for the United States Senate, but his proposals sound as sweeping as any president's since Lyndon B. Johnson's Great Society. He envisions a national health care system, with insurance for everyone. A national program of long-term care for the aged and infirm. And enough new federal education spending to cover college tuition for every high school graduate with a B average or better, and preschool for every toddler.

headline.main: Corzine Gives Broad Plans For Health And Schools

docs.abstract: Jon S Corzine discusses his candidacy for United States Senate from New Jersey; he discusses his proposals for national health care system, with insurance for everyone and long term care for aged and infirmed; calls for enough new Federal education spending to cover college tuition for every high school graduate with B average or better as well as preschool for every toddler; his candidacy rests on two propositions: that society awash in prosperity, its confidence buoyed by rising surpluses, should be ready to spend liberally to solve its most vexing social problems and that legal guardian of nation's purse strings should besomeone like him, Wall Street-hardened financier; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A month ago, Gov. George W. Bush was a battered victor in the presidential race, seemingly beholden to right-wing leaders who had rescued his candidacy. Vice President Al Gore appeared set to dominate the issues with proposals on health, children, schools and the environment. But lately Mr. Bush has shifted tactics -- releasing a barrage of domestic proposals, appearing at urban schools and meeting with gay Republicans. He seems eager to retrieve the ''compassionate conservative'' label and flesh it out. The governor's proposals have good features and flaws. They are also costly and somewhat undercut by his Texas record. But they bring a welcome new phase to the campaign. Since clinching the G.O.P. nomination, Mr. Bush has proposed an increase in education spending, a tax credit to help families buy health insurance, a proposal to clean up toxic ''brown fields'' and other measures. His military and domestic spending proposals would add $86 billion to the budget over five years. It is fair to ask how the governor would pay for everything while saving Social Security and Medicare, retiring the debt and cutting taxes. Indeed, both Mr. Gore and Mr. Bush may have to be more careful about using up surpluses that could shrink because of declines in the stock market or a possible economic downturn.
docs.abstract: Editorial says Gov George W Bush has recently released barrage of domestic proposals, seemingly eager to retrieve 'compassionate conservative' label and flesh it out; says his proposals have good features and flaws, and they are somewhat undercut by his Texas record, but they bring welcome new phase to campaign

docs.lead_paragraph: John deKoven Alsop, a veteran of Connecticut Republican politics, a former gubernatorial candidate and a retired insurance company president, died April 6 at a health care center in Old Saybrook, Conn. He was 84 and lived in Old Lyme, where he had moved from Avon, his birthplace, in 1986. Mr. Alsop, who served two terms in the state legislature in the late 1940's, was allied with the liberal wing of his party. He came to wider attention as an early backer of Dwight D. Eisenhower for president, and was a state vice chairman for

docs.lead_paragraph: I am one of some 30,000 people who discovered last year that their Social Security numbers had been pilfered. The theft of my identity actually began in 1996, when I was living overseas. Without my knowledge, someone had used my Social Security number to order telephone service in Los Angeles County, then disappeared, owing the phone companies thousands of dollars. I moved back to New York City in 1997 and rented an apartment, but in time, the phone companies sent the unpaid bills to collection agencies and the agencies, unable to recover the debts, passed the information on to three major national credit bureaus. I was labeled a financial delinquent. I didn't find out about my status until last year, when I tried to rent another apartment in New York. After weeks of hunting, I found a place I liked. The landlord said I could move in as soon as he ran the routine credit check. The next day he told me my negative credit rating made me too risky a tenant.

headline.main: How I Lost My Good Name

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Stacy Sullivan recounts her six-month battle trying to clear her name and regain her good credit rating after her Social Security number was pilfered and used to order various services; describes Kafkaesque maze of credit bureaus and collection agencies; says now, four years since her identity was stolen, unpaid bills are still reflected on her credit rating, preventing her from renting an apartment, among other things; says issuers of credit cards should take precautions to identify their customers

docs.lead_paragraph: A small health care revolution that has brought dozens of badly needed family doctors to new clinics in New York City's poorest neighborhoods is beginning to unravel, health and hospital experts say. The clinics had been multiplying in the city since the early 1990's, embraced as an efficient and affordable alternative to hospital emergency rooms, an all-too-frequent source of basic care for poor patients. But they have been seriously undermined in the last few years by a sea change in health care financing, the experts said.

headline.main: Financial Struggles At Medical Clinics For the City's Poor

docs.abstract: Health and hospitals experts say small health care revolution that brought dozens of badly needed family doctors to new clinics in New York City's poorest neighborhoods is beginning to unravel; health centers are trying to cope with rapid rise in uninsured patients in last few years; they have been hammered by heavy reductions in reimbursements from managed-care companies and from Medicaid program, which pays bills for majority of clinics' paying patients; 80 percent of community health care clinics in city lost money at some point over last four years; clinics were envisioned as more cost-effective way to provide routine care in neighborhoods where there are few doctors in private practice, and where people in need of medical care go to hospital emergency rooms for treatment; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George W. Bush met with a dozen gay Republicans and pronounced himself psychically refreshed. ''I'm a better person for the meeting,'' Mr. Bush said. Ralph Reed, who is a senior consultant to the Bush campaign, acknowledged that his consulting firm had been lobbying Mr. Bush on behalf of the Microsoft Corporation and pronounced it a mistake.

headline.main: Taking a Little Time Out for Making Amends

docs.lead_paragraph: The University Hospital and the Atlantic Health System, which includes Morristown Memorial, Mountainside and Overlook hospitals and General Hospital Center at Passaic, had both announced plans to terminate their contracts with Aetna U.S. Healthcare at the end of the month. But last week the insurer reached agreements to continue with the hospitals. Aetna U.S. Healthcare is New Jersey's largest health insurer with 1.1 million clients. If the contracts were terminated, those people who are part of Aetna's H.M.O. would not have been covered for care at the hospitals. The hospitals had said that Aetna's reimbursement rates were not enough to cover costs and that reimbursement was being denied in four times as many cases as other insurance companies. No details of the agreements were provided. KAREN DeMASTERS
